citation.article-title: Numerical and chemical classification of Actinoplanes and some related actinomycetes

p.s: Streptosporangiaceae (Strep'to.spo.ran.gi.um. ML n. Streptosporangium, type genus of the family; -aceae, ending to denote a family; ML fem. pl. n. Streptosporangiaceae, the Streptosporangium family)
The description is taken from the literature (Farina & Bradley, 1970; Stackebrandt et al., 198 1 ; Goodfellow & Cross, 1984; Goodfellow et al., 1988 ; Goodfellow, 1989).
Aerobic, Gram-positive, non-acid-fast actinomycetes that form stable substrate and aerial mycelium.

Aerial hyphae may carry chains of two (Microbispora) or more (Microtetraspora) spores or be differentiated into sporangia (spore vesicles) containing one (Planomonospora), two (Planobispora) or more spores (Streptosporangium).
Spores are either nan-motile (Microbispora, Microtetraspora Streptosporangium) or motile (Planomonospora, Planobispora).
Cell walls contain meso-diaminopimelic acid and N-acetylated muramic acid, but lack characteristic sugars.
The peptidoglycan is of the Aly type.

Lipid profiles typically contain saturated, iso- and anteiso- fatty acids, major proportions of unsaturated di- and hexahydrogenated menaquinones with nine isoprene units, and glucosamine-containing polar lipids.
The G + C content of the DNA lies within the range 66-74 mol%.
Nucleic acid pairing and sequencing data serve to distinguish the family from other suprageneric groups of actinomycetes.
Comparative studies on well-chosen representative strains are needed to clarify the taxonomic structure of the family Streptosporangiaceae.

The constituent genera are still separated using morphological features (Goodfellow, 1989) but have also been distinguished in a numerical taxonomic survey of wall chemotype III sporoactinomycetes (Good fellow & Pirouz, 1982).
Nevertheless, there is evidence that the genera Microbispora and Microtetraspora are closely related albeit heterogeneous taxa (Goodfellow & Cross, 1984; Poschner et al., 1985).

Thus, Microtetraspora viridis has been transferred to the genus Actinomadura as Actinomadura viridis whereas the type species of the genus, Microtetraspora glauca, belongs to the family Streptosporangiaceae (Miyadoh et al., 1989).
